required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 03, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Medical Masks vs N95 Respirators for COVID-19
clinical_study.official_title: Medical Masks Versus N95 Respirators to Prevent 2019 Novel Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) in Healthcare Workers: A Randomized Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
A randomized controlled trial in which nurses will be randomized to either medical masks or
      N95 respirators when providing care to patients with COVID-19.

detailed_description.textblock:
A randomized controlled trial in which nurses will be randomized to either medical masks or
      N95 respirators when providing medical care to patients with COVID-19. This Canadian
      multi-centre randomized controlled trial will assess whether medical masks are non-inferior
      to N95 respirators when nurses provide care involving non-aerosol generating procedures.
      Nurses will be randomized to either use of a medical mask or to a fit-tested N95 respirator
      when providing care for patients with febrile respiratory illness. The primary outcome is
      laboratory confirmed COVID-19 among nurse participants.

primary_outcome.description: Number of participants with RT-PCR confirmed COVID-19 infection

secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants with acute respiratory illness
Number of participants with lower respiratory infection
Number of participants with ICU admission
Number of participants needing mechanical ventilation

arm_group.description: Medical Mask worn when providing care to patient with febrile respiratory illness
N95 respirator worn when providing care to patient with febrile respiratory illness

intervention.description: Medical Mask (known also as Surgical Mask)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Nurses who work > 37 hours per week in medical, emergency, pediatric units

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Nurses with one or more comorbidities

          -  Nurses who cannot pass an N95 respirator fit-test
